subject: Re: [junit] testing private methods
msgSnippet: ... Hm. Not a good answer, but if you re losing precision after 1M iterations of a loop, then you simply gotta have a test for that. If that test takes minutes
messageBody:
>Accessing private fields may go into the same direction, but it can
>sometimes be quite useful:
>
>- what if the state of you objects suddenly become unstable? For
>example, somewhere a private long variable becomes 0 because of some
>heavy computation and loss of precision (due to / or * for example).
>Your unit test may still be ok (first iteration of your methods) but it
>may be difficult to simulate the 10,000th iteration, or 1,000,000th
>iteration. Accessing private fields may help you to quickly reset your
>classes into some state (like in a debugger). But maybe JUnit is not
>the right tool for this kind of problems.

Hm. Not a good answer, but if you're losing precision after 1M iterations of
a loop, then you simply gotta have a test for that. If that test takes
minutes to run, then it's entirely possible that your calculation needs to
be broken down into something less costly to test. Without a concrete
example, I can't say more. :)

>- when testing, you should ensure that the state of your object is valid
>(pre and post conditions). If you use private variables and don't
>expose them via getters, it's difficult to assert their values (assert
>in Jdk1.4 is nice, inner classes are ugly)

ARGH! This violently breaks the beautiful encapsulation property that helps
define OO programming. If you want to know whether an object is valid, send
it the message "isValid()". Let the object itself figure that out. If you
want to know whether an object satisfies its pre- and postconditions, the
object itself is the best judge. Send it "verifyPrecondition()" or
"verifyPostcondition()". There is no reason to break encapsulation, which is
the single most well-known anti-OO-pattern out there.

Of course, it's annoying to add those methods to every object, so judge
whether it's important. In this one instance, it's a pity that Java isn't
more like Eiffel.

We routinely add isValid() methods to our model objects. It's especially
useful when populating a model object from a ResultSet and from parameters
in an HTTP request.
